column1: #Text=
#Text=Codebase for easy specification of (conditional) (V-information) probing experiments.
#Text=Input-fields, for `conll`-formtted files, provides string labels for the columns of the file.
#Text=These identifiers will be used to pull the data of a column in the `AnnotationDataset` class; we'll go over this when we get to the `dataset` part of the config.
#Text=The cache object does some simple filesystem timestamp checking, and non-foolproof lock checking, to determine whether cache files for each dataset should be read from, or written to.

#Text=This is crucial for running many experiments with Huggingface `transformers` models, since the tokenization and alignment of subword tokens to corpus tokens takes more time than running the experiment itself once loaded.
#Text=Note that we make reference ids for both the WholeDatasetCache object itself and for the `{train,dev,test}` file paths, so we can use these later.
#Text=The `Reader` objects are written to handle the oddities of a given filetype.

#Text=The `OntonotesReader` object, for example, reads `conll` files, turning lines into sentences (given the `input_fields` object, above), while the `SST2Reader` object knows how to read `label\\TABtokenized_sentence` data, as given by the `SST2` task of the GLUE benchmark.
#Text=The `args` bit here is sort of a vestigal part of earlier code design; its only member, the `device`, is used whenver PyTorch objects are involved, to put tensors on the right device.
#Text=Note how it references the dataset filepaths that were registered in the cache part of the config.

#Text=The `ListDataset` object is always the top-level object of the `dataset` key; its job is to gather together output labels, and all of the input types, concatenate together the input, and yield minibatches for training and evaluation.
#Text=It is given the `DataLoader` from above so it can read data from disk.
#Text=It has a single specified `Dataset` for its output, here an `AnnotationDataset`.

#Text=The `AnnotationDataset` given here takes in a `Task` object -- here a `TokenClassificationTask`, to provide the labels for the output task. the `TokenClassificationTask` provides a label, using the `task_name` to pick out a column from the conll input file, as labeled by the `input_fields` list.
#Text=The `input_datasets` argument is a list of `Dataset` objects.
#Text=All of these datasets' representations are bundled together by the `ListDataset`.

#Text=Here, we only have one element in the list, a `HuggingfaceData` object, which runs the huggingface model specified by the `model_string`, but we could add a representation by adding another entry to the list.
#Text=The `HuggingfaceData` tokens and subword-to-corpus token alignment matrices will be read or written according to the `cache` given.
#Text=The `Dataset` generates (subword) tokens and alignment matrices, or label indices -- whatever a model needs as input.
#Text=Note that tasks like part-of-speech and dependency label, which have independent token-level labels, are easily exchangable in the `TokenClassificationTask`.

#Text=But to run a task like named entity recognition, with its specialized specification of entity-level annotation (and evaluation, later), specialized classes are needed, like `NERClassificationTask`.
#Text=For each dataset in `input_datasets`, a corresponding model takes the raw tokens provided by a `Dataset`, and runs the corresponding model to turn the input into a representation.
#Text=So, a `HuggingfaceData` above corresponds to a `HuggingfaceModel` here.
#Text=The `HuggingfaceModel` class runs the transformer model, and provides the representations of the layer at index `index`.
#Text=The `trainable` flag specifies whether to backprogate gradients back through the model and update its weights during training.
#Text=The `Probe` classes turn the representations given by `Model` classes into the logits of a distribution over the labels of the output task.
#Text=Somewhat unfortunately, it needs to be explicitly told what input and output dimensionality to expect.
#Text=The regimen specifies a training procedure, with learning rate decay, loss, etc.
#Text=Most of this is hard-coded right now to sane defaults.
#Text=There's only one trainer as of now.
#Text=By convention, I put results directories at `<path_to_config>.results`.
#Text=The reporter class takes predictions at the end of training, and reports evaluation metrics.
#Text=For each of the strings in `reporting_methods`, a reporter function (which is specified by a hard-coded map from reporting string to function) is run on the data.
#Text=The result of the metric is written to `<reporting_root>/<split>.
#Text=Note that some reporters and metrics are specialized to a task.
#Text=For example, SST2 has its own `SST2Reporter` (though it's really just a sentence-level classification reporter)
#Text=and named entity recognition has its own `NERReporter`, which calls the Stanza library's NER evaluation script.

#Text=Take a look at our [CodaLab executable paper](https://worksheets.codalab.org/worksheets/0x46190ef741004a43a2676a3b46ea0c76) for the exact bash scripts we ran to reproduce all the numbers in the paper.
#Text=The configs that govern each of the experiments are under
#Text=where `task_name` is one of `ptb_pos, upos, dep_rel, named_entities, sst2`.
#Text=For an example of an NER config (e.g., using span-based eval), see
#Text=For an example of a sentiment config (e.g., averaging the word embeddings for a sentence embedding), see
#Text=See the `scripts/ontonotes_scripts` directory for notes on how we prep ontonotes.

#Text=The scripts we use exactly recreate the splits of [Strubell et al., 2017](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.02098.pdf), a well-used split that, due to changes in preprocessing script versioning and link rot over the years of CoNLL and Ontonotes, had become (to us) difficult to re-create.
#Text=As such, to the greatest extent possible, we just paste the exact scripts here instead of linking to them.
#Text=If you just want the data, it's a few steps:
#Text=Let `ldc_ontonotes_path` be the path to your LDC download of `Ontonotes 5.0`, that is, `LDC2013T19`.
#Text=Unfortunately, we can't host this for you.
#Text=Next, due to some regrettable firewalling, our script to download the train/dev/test split information fails, so you have to navigate via a browser to:
#Text=and manually download `conll-2012-train.v4.tar.gz`, `conll-2012-development.v4.tar.gz`, and then navigate to the `test` folder and download `conll-2012-test-key.tar.gz`.
#Text=Place these files in the `scripts/ontonotes_scripts/` directory of this repository.
#Text=If you use this repository, please cite:
#Text=        author =      "Hewitt, John and Ethayarajh, Kawin and Liang, Percy and Manning, Christopher D.",
#Text=        title =       "Conditional probing: measuring usable information beyond a baseline",
#Text=        booktitle =   "Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing",
